message: San Diego is the example to follow...
Yes--I did.

Today is law enforcement appreciation day.  To all those who protect and serve--THANK YOU.  Also, here's my commentary today, posted to Fox News.
Doing TV first thing in the morning...

How our liberal LA Times' owned paper in San Diego--The San Diego Union-Tribune--portrays standing up for our men and women in law enforcement across the U.S. I haven't relented on a thing--in fact, the Speaker told me today that the abhorrent painting will be taken down and kept off the walls of the U.S. Capitol.  To the liberal media, it's about a painting on a canvas when in reality its about supporting law enforcement and appreciating the men and women who put their lives on the line every day, especially in the face of recent, targeted cop killings.
First time I met Mattis was in Diwaniya, Iraq.  He chewed my a** for not killing the terrorists who shot up my convoy on the way north from Kuwait.  He's going to help make America Great Again.
My response to a new report this morning questioning whether General James Mattis committed war crimes in Fallujah, Iraq in April 2004.  I was there--as an Artillery Officer.

John Kelly crushed it yesterday with the U.S. Senate during his hearing to serve as the next Secretary of Homeland Security.   I met Kelly for the first time in Hillah, Iraq in 2003, when we were both Marines.  He too will help Make America Great Again.
Heartbroken that the Chargers are going to leave San Diego--pending a miracle.

Kudos to Speaker Ryan.  This was never about a painting, for me.  It was about how we as an institution signal our support to the men and women who serve and protect, and stand on the thin blue line.   Hang it somewhere else--just not in the Capitol.  I'm happy it's coming down for good, Friday.
My take...

Two reasons for optimism: Mattis and Kelly--Defense and Homeland Security, respectively.  My op-ed today on these two leaders.  An excerpt:   "The media often caricatures rather than analyzes its subjects. Marine generals, especially those with colorful nicknames, are often pigeonholed as overly aggressive and less than analytical when facing complex situations.  "Any attempt to portray Marine Gen. James Mattis, President-elect Trump’s nominee for secretary of Defense and Gen. John Kelly, nominee for secretary of Homeland Security as “attack now and sort ‘em out later” military types overlooks the truth about two of America’s finest leaders — military or civilian."

More great reporting from Military Times. I've looked at valor awards in part to ensure our service men and women are rightly honored, but also because the process has been overly politicized and used as a mechanism to punish and retaliate.  Just look at the cases of Marine Lt Brian Chontosh, Sgt. Rafael Peralta, Major Matt Golsteyn and Earl Plumlee, among many others.  Excerpt:  "At first glance, it seems low," said Congressman Duncan Hunter, who served in Iraq and Afghanistan as a Marine officer. A California Republican, he has advocated on behalf of fellow veterans who've had awards downgraded and, as a member of the House Armed Services Committee, has been among the most high-profile to declare the military awards process both flawed and politicized. Hunter said he intends to examine each of the services' findings, once they're complete and made public.   "The one major fact I keep going back to that blows my mind is not a single living person received the Medal of Honor for the Iraq war," the congressman told Military Times, referencing the exploits of a Marine officer, 1st Lt. Brian Chontosh, who received the Navy Cross for charging on foot through more than 200 yards of trench in Iraq. After depleting his own ammunition, Chontosh used discarded enemy weapons to kill more than 20 fighters who'd ambushed his Marines. "Let's see if they remedied that — because that's just absurd," Hunter added. "And let's see if they looked at some of the bigger cases, or if they just took the low-hanging fruit."
NA

"Dozens of schools have already declared themselves sanctuaries and many more are debating the move, and Rep. Duncan Hunter, California Republican, has now introduced legislation to try to stop them by stripping some federal funds.  "'This effort is not about telling colleges who they can and can’t accept for enrollment, but whatever decision they make will either mean they receive federal money or they don’t — it’s that simple,' Mr. Hunter said."
My commentary today.
NA

"With bills that became law in 2016, Rep. Duncan Hunter, R-Alpine, got more legislation enacted than another other [San Diego] member. [Among] His successful bills include two Coast Guard authorization acts... 'And that doesn’t even include the mountain of amendments he’s included in the annual National Defense Authorization Act,' said Joe Kasper, Hunter’s chief of staff."

Today I led a bipartisan letter—along with fellow veteran Adam Kinzinger—to request the President direct a visa exception for military interpreters and aides who worked alongside U.S. troops.  Secretary of Defense James Mattis asked the same.
A true hero.
Early morning on FOX News to discuss my recent request to the President that was supported by a bipartisan group of House members, most of them vets.
Offered the opposing viewpoint in USA Today on the issue of whether Congress--and Republicans, in particular--should question the President's early use of executive authority.

I’ve worked a lot of military cases over the years – but few have received the same attention as Marine Corps Sgt Rafael Peralta, who smothered a grenade in Fallujah, Iraq.  He was nominated for the Medal of Honor but the award was downgraded because of politics.  I then led the effort to get a ship in his name.  And now that ship has been turned over to the Navy and will carry his name everywhere in the world, and inspire sailors and Marines, and serve as a testament to his courage and sacrifice.

Why we fight.   Yesterday, I asked James Mattis to reopen Sgt Peralta’s posthumous MoH nomination.  He too understands how the bureaucrats denied this high honor and how this case—among others—is proof of the politicization of the awards process.
This photo landed in my inbox today, taken by a friend.  Had to share.   --Uncommon Valor was a Common Virtue.
Secretary Mattis is not frightened by Pentagon bureaucrats.  If there’s anyone who can help get this done, it’s Mattis.
Leading by example...

.... the wall along the southwest border could cost Mexico more than just the price of building it: An official estimated that cartels send a stunning $64 billion worth of drugs into the U.S. every year...  Building the wall, which Trump famously said Mexico will pay for, will stop the twin tides of illegal immigrants and deadly drugs, said Rep. Duncan Hunter, R-Calif.  “Drug smugglers will always get creative and look for new ways to evade law enforcement, but without any kind of infrastructure we’re essentially inviting them to cross the land border either on vehicle or by foot,” Hunter told Fox News. “In San Diego, the double-fence halted vehicle drug drive throughs—in other words, there haven’t been any.   Hunter said improvements in the fencing and Border Patrol strategies have dropped the smuggling of people and narcotics significantly.   “Fencing can cut off major corridors for smugglers and it’s a force multiplier for the Border Patrol that either stops crossing attempts or slows them down enough for agents to respond,” Hunter said.

Still leading the effort to counter Russian expansion in the Arctic.  And even as ice melts, opening access even more, we’ll need a stronger Arctic presence for research, commerce and national security.  Right now, the Coast Guard has a requirement for 6 new icebreakers, and I’m working to accelerate the acquisition strategy to avoid delays, cost overruns and lost force projection... yesterday's report from the Washington Times puts things in good perspective.  Excerpt:    "Rep. Duncan Hunter, a California Republican whose House subcommittee oversees Coast Guard policy, said the U.S. is losing the battle for the Arctic and needs to fight back with at least one basic weapon — icebreakers — to ensure American access. Russia deploys nearly 40, the U.S. only two.  ""The U.S. Coast Guard says it needs three “medium” and three “heavy” ice plows but sails only the 1970s Polar Star (heavy) and the 2000 Healy (medium) in what is an increasingly busy and contested region.  "Mr. Hunter, chairman of the House Transportation and Infrastructure subcommittee on Coast Guard and maritime transportation, has been working behind the scenes to help the Coast Guard (which operates on a relatively small $10 billion budget) to press Congress and the White House for more money.  "He also arranged a marriage between the Coast Guard’s ship-buying office and the Navy so that the Coast Guard can reap some of the larger service’s expertise. The Coast Guard has not designed and bought a heavy icebreaker in decades."
NA
Any confusion about where I stand on what U.S. Marines are capable of doing—now in Syria? Watch my interview this morning to find out.
Second TV spot today -- this one on "Trump trying to be taken down from the inside."

I was honored to be in the company of various CA law enforcement associations and their members this weekend.  I was also presented with a Blue Line hat for standing up for police officers nationwide [for personally removing the painting from the Capitol that depicted officers as pigs].  Our police officers put their lives on the line everyday—and I’m grateful for what they do and the sacrifices they make.
Had a great time with KUSI [San Diego] yesterday... check out the conversation.  Discussed health care, protests and the U.S. Coast Guard.

Great [but cold] morning with students from Literacy First Charter School in El Cajon...

"Rep. Duncan Hunter, a California Republican who was one of the first to expose the surge of Haitians last year and has tracked the issue since, said all it took was a commitment of enforcement to stem the flow." ... And it happened without new legislation. No new authorities. Just exposure and action.
Great news – court justifies removal of painting depicting cops as pigs.  It’s removal was appropriate and necessary—and I was more than happy to take the lead and pull it down.

Linked up with Wolf Blitzer yesterday to talk North Korea.  One point: Let’s trust the military minds that are most knowledgeable on what if anything we should do—that’s the new and respected National Security Advisor, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs and the Secretary of Defense.  That’s an impressive leadership lineup and if we can’t trust them, then there’s nobody we can trust with our military.
Good time with KUSI this morning.  Covered a lot of ground.

My take on Syria…   “The authorization by President Donald Trump to launch dozens of Tomahawk missiles at targets in Syria signaled to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and the rest of the world that America’s tolerance for provocations and threats has finally waned.   “No longer should we expect meaningless red lines or disadvantageous diplomatic pursuits that have an emboldening effect on adversaries that have either viewed America as weak or sought to attack the nation’s interests.  In just a few short months, President Trump has been decisive and unapologetic, whereas his predecessor was just the opposite …   “…A good way forward for President Trump and his national security team is to now leverage the missile strike to force Assad to the negotiation table in order to establish a reasonable path to peace.  Contingent should be the welcoming of an objective and independent inspection team to have a closer look at the claims and counter-claims around the use of chemical weapons—to ascertain the facts and inform any subsequent push for accountability and consequence to the furthest degree possible.    "Any suggestion of submitting a ground force into Syria or initiating operations to remove Assad from power is a failure to learn the lessons of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.  It can be done, but at tremendous cost, including lives.  Much like Iraq will never mirror the U.S. in politics and culture, we should not presume that Syria’s population centers could one day resemble a place like San Diego, California, or that a Syrian government is capable of one day resembling what we’ve come to know and expect from our own political institutions.”

One of my favorite things to do is visit small businesses and innovators, which I did yesterday and have more lined up this week.  Here I met and spoke with employees at Daylight Solutions, and saw some state of the art laser technology used for cancer detection.  I was sure to thank them for what they’re doing for health care and military research.

In case you missed my op-ed in Sunday’s UT… With President Trump looking to find efficiencies and consolidate the federal government, I’ve suggested moving the Coast Guard to DoD—to both advance the CG mission and gain better return on investment.

Great meeting with Mayors from North County San Diego.  Conversation centered on transportation issues—and as a member of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee in the House, I’ll be taking back to DC their concerns and recommendations.

My latest op-ed on action taken by CBP to uphold The Jones Act in protection of energy infrastructure and resources.  The Jones Act, in fact, is the quintessential definition of “Buy American, Hire American.”
Fast fact: Congress has sent 29 bills to the President’s desk—the most for a President’s first 100 days since 1949.

Regulations imposed under President Obama that treat vaping no differently than tobacco hurt smokers who want to reduce their urge or quit altogether, as well as small businesses [in San Diego and elsewhere] that sell products to consumers wanting the benefits of harm reduction.  The bill I introduced today will better help smokers quit smoking and provide clarity and relief to small businesses everywhere.

"Both pieces of legislation – the Cole-Bishop bill and the Hunter bill – make sense from a public health policy perspective. Far from protecting Big Tobacco, they make it more difficult to market deadly tobacco cigarettes by ensuring that competition from much safer tobacco-free vapor products can continue. They are a great start to correcting the lunacy of today's federal regulation..."
My [very candid] conversation with the airline CEOs today…

From FOX News today--a day in my life as a Congressman.  I'm honored to be considered the Warfighter's Congressman but it's the men and women who serve that motivate me to take on the fights that I do.
"None of what has incited controversy should be seen as altering the view that Russia is a competitor that will take advantage of any weakness..." My op-ed in USA Today on Russia.
Border agents becoming ill and military exercises suspended due to Mexican sewage spill.  Requested action today.
Congratulations to Ramona resident Alexander Richardson--who is graduating from the Naval Academy and will soon be commissioned as an Ensign.  Wishing him the best of luck.
Tax reform still a top priority.

Today, as we reflect on the horrific attacks on America 16 years ago, it is clear that terrorists organizations are still trying to do us harm.  We must continue to be vigilant.  Our Armed Forces and their families make sacrifices every day to protect our freedom here at home and abroad.  As the fight against terrorism continues, I encourage you to remember the men and women in uniform, as well as our first responders, who work tirelessly to keep us free and safe. Semper Fi.

Last week, the House passed important legislation that provides critical funding for emergency disaster response and relief to the victims and those impacted by Hurricane Harvey.  While additional funding will be needed in the near future, this bill fully met the Administration’s request and I am proud to have supported it.  However, after receiving the bill, the Senate worked a deal with Democrats to take advantage of this situation and attached a provision raising the debt limit to the bill.  This is disappointing.  While I believe the emergency spending bill is critically needed, I cannot support raising the debt limit in this manner.  It is for this reason that I voted against the final passage of the emergency spending bill when it passed the House late last week.  This issue should have been addressed separately and the Senate should have passed a clean version of the disaster relief bill as the House did originally.
Great friend and outstanding Marine.

Last week, I joined several of my congressional colleagues in introducing two important pieces of legislation critical in the ongoing effort to curb illegal immigration, the Legal Workforce Act, and the Immigration in the National Interest Act.

My message to the President is straightforward and clear; I will not support any immigration reform effort, including DACA, that does not address border enforcement and put national security first.  Period.  Read my full letter to President Trump below.

Great day at Camp Pendleton.  Had the honor to attend the pinning ceremony of now Chief Petty Officer Moe Dianat, significant other to Angelica Rodriguez, a US Navy veteran on my staff.  Made a visit to the Naval Hospital and talked with Commanding Officer CAPT Pearson about the recent training accident at the base where an amphibious assault vehicle caught fire injuring 15 of our Marines.  Finally, visited a future independent energy site allowing the base to assist with air drops during fire emergencies, even when the power is out.  The San Diego region is critical to our national defense infrastructure and Camp Pendleton is an important component.  #SemperFi  #CampPendleton

Last week, the House passed H.R. 3354, the Make America Secure and Prosperous Appropriations Act of 2018.  This legislation provides funding for critical federal programs that Americans rely on every day while, at the same time, reducing wasteful spending.  Below are some important provisions contained in the bill that you might be interested in, as well as a link to the House Appropriations website with full detail.  Bottom line is that, while I believe there is much more to do, we are heading in the right direction with this funding bill.   Important provisions that I support include:   • Fully funding the President’s request to build a wall along our southern border (although this is just a start); • Rolling back burdensome, job-killing regulations; • Protecting Second Amendment rights; • Preventing the implementation of the Obamacare individual mandate; • Authorizing the Environmental Protection Agency to withdraw from the Obama administration’s harmful Waters of the U.S. (WOTUS) rule; • Providing the highest level of funding ever for the Department of Veteran Affairs; • Giving our military a well-deserved pay increase; • Combating drug abuse in our communities; • Protecting the sanctity of life here at home by defunding Planned Parenthood and enforcing the Mexico City Policy; • Providing funds for FEMA to respond to disasters.     https://appropriations.house.gov/legislation/

Had the honor to make remarks this morning at a press briefing with Attorney General Sessions, Congressman Darrell Issa and Coast Guard Commandant Admiral Paul F. Zukunft announcing record drug seizures.  The U.S. Coast Guard and its interagency partners seized over 455,000 pounds of cocaine worth more than $6 billion wholesale in Fiscal Year 2017 breaking the U.S. record for most cocaine seized in a single year.  Watch the video below and thank you men and women serving in our U.S. Coast Guard for your continued hard work and tireless efforts.  https://www.dvidshub.net/video/552927/us-coast-guard-cutter-stratton-offloads-more-than-50000-pounds-cocaine

Below is the letter that I sent to President Trump, urging him to support the results of the referendum in favor of independence as well as working with the Iraqi Kurdistan government and the Iraqi government to ensure an conflict free implementation of the referendum’s result.

Pleased to announce that the House passed our budget resolution today, H. Con. Res. 71, setting the stage for major tax reform while, at the same time, supporting serious realistic changes to eliminate our deficits and actually balance the budget in 10 years.  This budget also ensures that our military is properly funded and maintained at the highest level.  It is for these reasons that I voted for this budget resolution, which I believe is an important step toward creating greater efficiency and long-term solvency.  For more detailed information on our budget plan, please visit the House Budget Committee website: https://budget.house.gov/budgets/fy18/.  #balancethebudget #taxreform

New report from the National Association of Manufacturers (NAM) confirms that tax reform will encourage a majority of American manufacturers to raise wages and hire more workers.  As we move forward on the debate, it’s important to have the facts.

Great day with the American-Polish Cooperation Society and Mt. Soledad Memorial Association honoring Gen. Merian C. Cooper.  Gen. Cooper served with distinction during WWI, the Mexican Expedition, the Polish-Soviet War and WWII.  Cooper was a great American hero and in between his military service, also had a great career in the film industry, directing the original King Kong and producing many western films with Hollywood legend John Wayne.
Just introduced bipartisan legislation on education reform and helping create American jobs. Check it out below.

Toured the Workshop for Warriors in San Diego with their founder, Hernan Luis y Prado.  Great program that allows Vets to become certified in numerous manufacturing job skills at no cost.  This program has earned a 100 percent job placement rating with the median wage of 60k a year after 16 weeks of free training and certification.  Workshop for Warriors serves veterans from every branch of our Armed Forces so if you are interested in learning more, visit their website at www.wfwusa.org.

In 1985, DEA Special Agent Enrique “Kiki” Camarena was brutally murdered by Mexican drug traffickers.  Today we celebrate Red Ribbon Week to honor his legacy as well as bring awareness to students, individuals, and communities about the dangers of drug abuse.  As President Trump recently outlined, the prescription drug and heroin epidemic is a matter of great national importance.  Ensuring there are adequate treatment options is crucial, as are preventative initiatives against the development of opioid dependence.  To address these problems, Congress passed two important pieces of legislation, the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act and the 21st Century Cures Act.  Both measures, which were signed into law at the end of last year, are aimed at combating this ongoing problem.  Further, in this year’s funding bill, Congress included $781 million toward addiction education, prevention, treatment and, just as important, support for our local law enforcement who are our front line of defense with this issue.   There’s no doubt there is more work to be done.  Let’s use Red Ribbon Week 2017 as a reminder that as great as the opioid epidemic is, it’s a challenge we can overcome.
Great time at KUSI this morning talking tax reform, immigration and other important issues.  See full interview below.

We had a great time at the Lakeside VFW welcoming home the 670th MP CO: Street Fighters.  These first-responders helped protect victims of the recent wildfires in Northern California and we are very grateful for their continued service and dedication.

Yesterday, I joined Homeland Security Committee Chairman Michael McCaul [TX-10] along with members of the Homeland Security Committee at the Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach for a bipartisan field hearing to examine the physical security and cybersecurity of our nation’s ports.  Several officials from the Ports, the Coast Guard, Customs and Border Protection and the International Longshore and Warehouse Union testified on cybersecurity risks and vulnerabilities at our nation’s ports and what has been done to address these weaknesses.

Yesterday, my colleagues and I held a press conference at the U.S. Capitol to bring attention to the continuing threat of Iranian-backed Iraqi forces advancing in the Kurdistan region following a September 25th, 2017 vote calling for independence from Iraq. The Kurds have been strong allies of the United States and we need to stand by them.  See my remarks below.

Very excited about our tax reform package, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, a once-in-a-generation opportunity.  I want everyone to have all the facts so click on the link provided which will let you read the actual bill, review policy highlights and see examples of how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will help Americans of all walks of life.    Imagine a tax code so simple that you can fill out your taxes on the back of a postcard.  That's the goal, that's what we're working toward.  Let me know what you think.  https://waysandmeans.house.gov/taxreform/

I'm glad to see so many responses regarding the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act, but didn't take long for "tax cut for the rich" myth to be spread around.  John Adams once said, "Facts are stubborn things."  So let's have some facts about what the bill actually does:  • Lowers individual tax brackets for low and middle income Americans to 0, 12%, 25%, and 35%.  Rates for high-income Americans is maintained at 39.6%;  • Preserves the home mortgage interest deduction and the charitable contribution deduction;  • Maintains the write off for state and local property taxes up to $10,000.  • Increases the standard deduction to $12,000 for individuals and $24,000 for married couples;  • Doubles the exemption for the Death Tax and completely repeals the Death Tax in six years;  • Establishes a new Family Tax Credit, which expands the Child Tax Credit and preserves the Dependent Care Tax Credit;  • Retains popular retirement savings options such as 401ks and IRAs;  • Retains the low-income housing tax credit;  • Lowers the corporate tax rate to 20%;  • Allows businesses to write off the full cost of new equipment and the interest on loans;  All sounds good to me.

The Bradley Ave exit off Highway 67 continues to be a major infrastructure problem here in East County.  Its current condition causes extreme bottleneck congestion keeping the area from reaching its full economic potential in terms of growth and development.  It is for this reason improving this exit and bridge has been among my top priorities and I’m proud to once again team up with Congresswoman Susan Davis in supporting available federal grants for this project.
See my recent OpEd on tax reform from the Ramona Sentinel.

Today the U.S. Marine Corps celebrates its 242nd anniversary of serving our nation.  One of my greatest privileges was to stand beside men and women dedicated to the cause of freedom.  Each one of us shared a common bond completing a crucible of training to protect our nation against all threats and to tirelessly defend freedom, not just for ourselves, but for all Americans and our allies around the world.  On this important day, we remember Marines of past and present, who put this nation above their own interests and answered the call of duty.   To every man and woman who has been fortunate enough to earn the title of Marine, I say Semper Fi!

Honored to be asked to participate in the Veterans Day Celebration & Dedication Ceremony at the Alpine Veterans Wall of Honor this morning where 14 new plaques were installed. While we celebrate our veterans, it is far more important that we do right by them as well.  That is the subject of this piece I wrote for the The Press-Enterprise regarding the unnecessary bureaucracy California veterans face regarding utilizing the benefits they earned with the GI Bill.  Thank you to all veterans and their families for their service and sacrifice to our county.  #SemperFi
Proud to vote for a pay raise for our military service members today: http://ow.ly/F3ZD30gA9V4 #FY18NDAA
Lot of discussion about tax reform, please visit my website to learn how these changes will directly benefit those living in California’s 50th District.

Historic day for making America great again, House passes biggest tax reform bill in 30 years.  Visit my website for more details on how this will benefit California taxpayers.  Defining moment now for the Senate to help hard-working Americans.
Great roundtable discussion on tax reform and water issues this morning at Mary's Donuts in Lakeside.

This afternoon I met with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the San Diego Wildlife Federation to discuss the implementation of hunting and recreational shooting at the San Diego National Wildlife Refuge Complex and increased access to public lands.

Great opportunity to speak with students at UCSD's Strategic Studies Group about foreign policy and national security.  We had a good and spirited discussion on North Korea and military readiness.  Appreciate the invite and hearing different points of view.

2017 has been full of challenges, from wildfires here in California to destructive hurricanes in Texas and Puerto Rico.  At the same time, America has so very much for which to be thankful.  Like many others, my family has always celebrated Thanksgiving as a time to be together (our family tradition is hunting) and to focus on our blessings of family, friends, and the freedoms protected by our men and women serving in uniform.  California's 50th District is home to over 58,000 veterans and active duty service members.  We are grateful and proud of their service.  Many sacrifice time with their families so we may be with ours during the holidays.  From my family to yours, we wish you a Happy Thanksgiving and ask that your remember our military and first responders when you say your prayers around the table this year.

Today I re-introduced the Student Right to Know Before You Go Act, alongside a Senate version led by Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR). With the cost of higher education rapidly rising, students and their families must have access to more data about one of the more major financial decisions in one’s life in a secure, easy-to-read format. We have bipartisan support in both chambers---Let’s get it done!

Proud of the work we’ve done on the National Defense Authorization Act.  This bill will provide our warfighters with the tools they need to keep us safe at home and abroad.  Next Stop --> White House.

Steinle Family has been heavy on my heart since the asinine verdict last night.  Personally, I'm going to continue working on my legislation prohibiting federal funding to state, counties, cities and colleges that support sanctuary policies, but I'm also going to support any effort that helps ensure this criminal is prosecuted for any possible violation under the law.  #accountability
House passes Concealed Carry Reciprocity bill, long overdue, but great step forward for our 2nd Amendment and public safety.  Learn more by visiting my website.

Today marks the 76th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor – a pivotal moment in U.S. history.  America lost 2,403 U.S. service personnel, 68 civilians and all but three ships of the U.S. Pacific Fleet.  Despite this loss, we gained something that day as well.  The hard lesson that if America was to lead, we had to be prepared.   December 7, 1941 has personal significance to my family.  Following the attack on Pearl Harbor, my grandfather, Robert O. Hunter, joined the Marine Corps and trained as an artillery officer where he eventually took part in the invasion of the Philippines at Leyte Island in October 1944 under General Douglas MacArthur.  This call to service influenced my father, Duncan L. Hunter, who joined the U.S. Army in 1969 and served in Vietnam.  60 years later, on September 11, 2001, this call to service came full circle when I joined the Marine Corps after the terrorist attacks on our nation.  The living-example the survivors of Pearl Harbor provide is ensuring that our military has the proper resources to protect and defend our nation.  As a Marine combat veteran of Iraq and Afghanistan, I know the important lessons of Pearl Harbor and September 11 and I am unapologetically committed to keeping America safe and working on behalf of those who have taken on this responsibility.   As the years pass, the greatest generation gets smaller.  Only 558,000 of the 16 million men and women who served our nation in World War II are still alive today.  With each passing anniversary, let us never forget the thousands of Americans who were injured or lost their lives during the attack at Pearl Harbor, as well as the men and women who went to war to defend our freedom and serve alongside our allies.  Today I ask that you join me in honoring these heroes by sharing the name or photo of someone in your family who has served or is serving to defend our nation today.     #PearlHarborRememberanceDay

To receive updates on #LilacFire and #LibertyFire be sure to follow CAL FIRE San Diego/San Diego County Fire Authority, important information on safe travel routes, evacuation centers and other emergency information.
More information on local evacuation centers and resources through the American Red Cross.

My office is working with CAL FIRE and American Red Cross to get the most updated information on the ongoing wildfire situation.  Obviously, people should listen to local media for updates and critical information regarding evacuation procedures.  Other important safety steps include: •  Back your car into the garage or park it in an open space facing your direction of escape. •  Keep your pets in one room so you can find them quickly if you have to evacuate. •  Arrange for a temporary place to stay outside the threatened area. •  Keep your indoor air clean – close windows and doors to prevent the smoke outside from getting in your home. •  Use the recycle mode on the air conditioner in your home or car. If you don’t have air conditioning and it’s too hot to be inside, seek shelter somewhere else. •  If smoke levels are high, don’t use anything that burns and adds to air pollution inside such as candles, fireplaces and gas stoves.  STAY CONNECTED WITH LOVED ONES Visit the Red Cross Safe and Well website at www.redcross.org/safeandwell to reconnect with loved ones. The site allows individuals and organizations to register and post messages to indicate that they are safe, or to search for loved ones. The site is always available, open to the public and available in Spanish. Registrations and searches can be done directly on the website. Registrations can also be completed by texting SAFE to 78876. You can also use the “I’m Safe” feature of the Red Cross Emergency App to let loved ones know your status.

CAL FIRE San Diego/San Diego County Fire Authority is holding a community meeting at the Fallbrook Community Center at 7:00pm this evening to provide an operational briefing and answer questions.  Additionally, per the American Red Cross of San Diego/Imperial Counties, as #LilacFire evacuation orders in some areas have changed from mandatory to voluntary, the American Red Cross is consolidating shelter operations to Palomar College. Bostonia Park & Rec Center still open for those affected by the planned power outages in East County.

The County of San Diego has set up a Local Assistance Center (LAC) at the Vista Library located at 700 Eucalyptus Ave in Vista.  The LAC, which opens at 9:00 am tomorrow morning, will have resources to assist fire victims of the #LilacFire, including help with government agencies, recovery information, healthcare workers, mental health professionals and fire clean up kits.  Please visit the County's website at SDCountyRecovery.com for the most current information.

Through the leadership and hard work of CAL FIRE, #LilacFire is 92% contained.  As we transition from emergency response to rebuilding, I wanted to make everyone aware of the Local Assistance Center (LAC) at the Vista Library where people can go to receive help with every aspect of rebuilding.  From government offices to insurance providers, you will find it at the LAC.  Members of my staff are at the LAC to help with any questions regarding federal agencies and we were also able to arrange for a mobile Vet Center to be available on site to help anybody with VA issues.  Please visit the LAC at 700 Eucalyptus Ave in Vista from 9:00 am to 6:00 pm if you need any help.

Historic day....passing tax reform keeps an important promise to the American people.  I am very pleased that the final product of this bill addressed many of the initial concerns that were raised, including ensuring provisions for wildfire disaster relief, maintaining the adoption tax credit, and protecting deductions for charitable giving, mortgage interest, state and local taxes and medical expenses.  This tax bill is an investment in America’s future by bringing good-paying manufacturing jobs and investment dollars back to the U.S. from Mexico and overseas, it’s an investment in the American people who know best how to care for their families and their future.  This tax bill is an investment in which I am confident we are going to see immediate returns.  For additional information on the tax bill, please visit my website at https://hunter.house.gov/.

Update on the #LilacFire, Governor Brown has requested a major disaster declaration for the State of California that includes all affected areas in San Diego County.  If President Trump approves, and I am urging him to do so, this will allow FEMA to provide additional federal resources for rebuilding efforts.  I will continue to follow this important process and my office will be able to assist as we move forward.  If you would like review the declaration process in more detail, please visit FEMA at https://www.fema.gov/pdf/rrr/dec_proc.pdf.
NA
